items.content_html:
Description

The preflight request page's example sends an Access-Control-Request-Headers header, but the example response does not contain an Access-Control-Allow-Headers which is required. This PR simply adds one.

Motivation

Readers may believe that a server (wanting a preflight request to succeed) doesn't need to respond with an Access-Control-Allow-Headers header if the client sends an Access-Control-Request-Headers header.

Additional details

N/A

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Add missing CORS header in preflight response example

items.content_html:
FF123 supports Feature policy publickey-credentials-create to allow cross origin credential creation in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1870863

This adds a release note

Other docs work can be tracked in #31890
items.title: FF123 Relnote: WebAuthn credential createion in cross origin frames

items.content_html:
FF123 supports Feature policy publickey-credentials-create in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1870863
As per usual for FF, this can't be set on the header, but only via allow on the frame.

This attempts to update the docs with some corrections according to advice from engineers and my interpretation of the spec. Note that I think there are probably more relevant exceptions, but I don't propose to go through all the specs right now.

The specific issues fixed are:

  1. Docs say creating/getting a credential is a SecurityError. Spec says NotAllowedError in step 5 here
  2. If allow is declared in an iframe then transient activation is required on the iframe as well, or you get the same error.
  3. This explicitly said you can't use create() in an iframe, but that was changed in WebAuthn spec in w3c/webauthn#1801 and to the Credential Management spec in w3c/webappsec-credential-management#209. I added some examples.

I'm seeing confirmation from engineers too in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1870863#c7 but the spec seems fairly clear on the NotAllowedError and transient activation.

Other docs work can be tracked in #31890
items.title: FF123 updates for permission publickey-credentials-create

items.content_html:
Description

I added clarification that even today it is not possible to change Referr to any value

Motivation

The wording of the current documentation means that you can programmatically define any desired referrer completely freely, while in practice you can only define to remove it or set it to an address from the same origin (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch#referrer )

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update forbidden_header_name referer note

items.content_html:
Imported CommonModule (could only import NgFor instead) and set app component as standalone. Without importing NgFor, ngForOf won't bind to li used in the template. Angular expects the component to be standalone. There could be better ways to fix this, I'm writing this while going through the tutorial.

Description

Imported CommonModule and added standalone flag to app.components.ts. Otherwise the built app does not work as intended (or at all in the case of the standalone flag)

Motivation

Without these changes (or others, I am not the most knowledgeable) I was unable to proceed with the tutorial. There could be better fixes for the issues I encountered, but following the current instructions exactly does not work.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

I have not created an issue but upon my search of the word "angular" in issues and PRs there isn't anything about this problem.
items.title: Added changes to remove errors discovered while following instructions.

items.content_html:
This is based on my own testing on Chrome and Firefox, not something I saw in the spec or any other documentation. The simple-service-worker example has a two-line function, addResourcesToCache() that is called in only one place and is thus ripe for inlining. But I tried that while adapting the example to my project and it fails.

Prior to merging this change it would be great to confirm with someone knowledgeable that the facts are correct and that I'm not missing anything, like the proper way to structure an anonymous function here.

This might apply to FetchEvent: respondWith() too, but I want to confirm that this is for real before expanding the scope of testing and changes.
items.title: ExtendableEvent: waitUntil() does not accept anonymous functions
